headline.seo: To Combat Diabetes, Weight Loss Surgery Works Better Than Medicine, Studies Find
headline.print_headline: Surgery Is Found To Aid Diabetics
headline.main: Surgery for Diabetes May Be Better Than Standard Treatment

docs.abstract: Two studies, published in The New England Journal of Medicine, find that obese and overweight people who undergo weight-loss operations, like bariatric surgery, are more likely to have complete remission of Type 2 diabetes than people given non-surgical treatment; some surgeons and obesity experts are now pushing to establish a role for the surgeries in treating diabetes, not just obesity, while other experts, concerned over the risks and complications inherent in major surgery, say more research is needed.
docs.lead_paragraph: Bariatric surgery, in which the stomach is stapled and the small intestine rerouted, puts the disease into remission far more often than drugs, diet and exercise, researchers say.
docs.snippet: Bariatric surgery, in which the stomach is stapled and the small intestine rerouted, puts the disease into remission far more often than drugs, diet and exercise, researchers say.

headline.main: For Schoolyard Gardens, a Global Network

docs.abstract: A new social Web site shares the lessons and best practices of school gardens and lunch programs in the hope of supporting start-up gardens around the globe.
docs.snippet: A new social Web site shares the lessons and best practices of school gardens and lunch programs in the hope of supporting start-up gardens around the globe.

docs.abstract: Gray Matter column by Gayle Greene cautions against studies that have found that sleeping pills are dangerous; reflects on her own experience as an insomiac; argues while the risks of sleeping pills are real, so are the risks of sleep deprivation.
docs.lead_paragraph: The risks of sleeping pills are real, but so are the risks of sleep deprivation.
docs.snippet: The risks of sleeping pills are real, but so are the risks of sleep deprivation.

headline.main: Best Sellers: Hardcover Advice, How-To And Miscellaneous: Sunday, March 25th 2012

docs.lead_paragraph: About the Best Sellers: These lists are an expanded version of those appearing in the March 25, 2012 print edition of the Book Review, reflecting sales for the week ending March 10, 2012. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above it. A dagger (†) indicates that some retailers report receiving bulk orders. For an explanation of our methodology, visit http://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers.

headline.print_headline: No Backing Down in Women's Right to Compete
headline.main: No Backing Down in Women's Right to Compete

docs.lead_paragraph: The International Olympic Committee is steering things in the right direction, but far too many women remain unable to play sports in their home country.
docs.snippet: The International Olympic Committee is steering things in the right direction, but far too many women remain unable to play sports in their home country.
